Literature Review: Corporate taxation has been a subject of extensive research and debate in economics, with significant implications for policy-making and economic growth. This literature review aims to synthesize key findings and ongoing discussions in the field, focusing on corporate income taxation and its various impacts on the economy. One of the central issues in corporate taxation research is the incidence of the corporate income tax. Gravelle and Smetters (2006) conducted a comprehensive analysis of corporate tax incidence, challenging the conventional wisdom that the burden of corporate taxes falls primarily on capital owners. Their findings suggest that, under certain conditions, a significant portion of the tax burden can be shifted to labor through reduced wages. This perspective has been further explored by Suárez Serrato and Zidar (2016), who examined the incidence of state corporate taxes in the United States, finding that workers bear a substantial share of the corporate tax burden through lower wages. The effect of corporate taxation on investment and economic growth has been another crucial area of research. Djankov et al. (2010) conducted a cross-country study demonstrating that higher effective corporate tax rates are associated with lower levels of investment and entrepreneurship. This negative relationship between corporate taxes and investment has been corroborated by other studies, such as that of Zwick and Mahon (2017), who found that temporary tax incentives can significantly stimulate investment, particularly for small firms. International tax avoidance by multinational corporations has emerged as a major concern in recent years. Dharmapala (2014) provided a comprehensive review of the literature on base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS), highlighting the various strategies employed by multinational firms to reduce their tax liabilities. The research suggests that while profit shifting is a significant issue, its magnitude may be smaller than often perceived in policy debates. Tørsløv et al. (2018) further contributed to this discussion by estimating the scale of profit shifting to tax havens, finding that it amounts to about 40% of multinational profits. The role of corporate taxes in economic crises has also been a subject of research interest. Vegh and Vuletin (2015) examined the cyclicality of tax policy across countries and found that developing countries tend to implement procyclical tax policies, potentially exacerbating economic downturns. In contrast, developed countries generally adopt countercyclical or acyclical tax policies. This research highlights the importance of considering the timing and context of corporate tax changes in relation to economic cycles. The debate about taxes on windfall profits, particularly in times of crisis or unexpected economic shocks, has gained renewed attention. Auerbach and Poterba (1987) provided an early analysis of the economic effects of windfall profit taxes, emphasizing the importance of careful design to minimize distortions and unintended consequences. More recently, Stiglitz (2015) has argued for the potential benefits of windfall profit taxes in addressing inequality and funding public investments, particularly in the context of economic crises. The efficiency and equity implications of corporate taxation have been extensively studied. Auerbach (2018) provided a comprehensive review of the literature on corporate tax reform, discussing various proposals and their potential impacts on economic efficiency and distribution. The research suggests that there is no clear consensus on the optimal corporate tax system, with trade-offs between efficiency, equity, and administrative feasibility. Finally, the interaction between corporate taxation and other areas of economic policy has been an important area of research. Desai and Dharmapala (2009) examined the relationship between corporate tax avoidance and corporate governance, finding that stronger governance can mitigate the negative effects of tax avoidance on firm value. This research highlights the importance of considering corporate taxation within the broader context of corporate finance and governance. In conclusion, the literature on corporate taxation reveals a complex and multifaceted field with significant implications for economic policy. While substantial progress has been made in understanding the effects of corporate taxes on various aspects of the economy, many questions remain open for further research. As global economic conditions continue to evolve, particularly in the face of crises and technological changes, the study of corporate taxation will undoubtedly remain a critical area of economic research and policy debate.
